CCA for Integration (Batch Effect Removal) Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) identifies correlated gene expression patterns between datasets, finding the directions that maximize covariation across them. Seurat uses these correlations to define anchors or pairs of biologically similar cells across datasets. These anchors then drive the creation of a new integrated assay, which contains batch-corrected expression values suitable for joint analysis (clustering, visualization, and DGE).

ðŸ”¹ 2. CCA and PCA for Label Transfer For label transfer, the goal shifts from merging datasets to mapping a new (query) dataset onto a labeled (reference) dataset. Here, Seurat again finds anchors, but instead of correcting expression values, it uses them for KNN-based label propagation: each query cell inherits information (e.g., cell type, PCA coordinates) from its k nearest anchors in the reference space. â€¢ CCA-based label transfer: anchors are found via correlated features (CCA). â€¢ PCA-based label transfer: anchors are found using mutual nearest neighbors (MNNs) in PCA space, followed by the same KNN-weighted propagation.
